# Electricity

- Electricity is the physical phenomenon that encompasses the motion of matter that has an electric charge. Common phenomena such as static electricity, lightning, electric heating, etc, exist due to electricity. 
- The presence of an electric charge which can be positive or negative produces an electric field. The movement of electric charges is known as current and produces a magnetic field. 
- When a charge is placed in a neutral location, a force will act on it. This is governed by Coulomb's Law. If the charge moves, the electric field would be doing *work* on the electric charge. 
- For example, a lightweight ball suspended with a string, when touched by a glass rod charged by a piece of cloth, it will be charged. Coulomb was a French engineer and physicist that deduced that electric charge is always opposing each other. 


## Electrical Charges
- Charges tend to spread themselves evenly across a conducting surface. The magnitude of the electromagnetic force is derived by Coulomb's law, in which $F = k \frac{|q_{1}q_{2}|}{r^{2}}$
![Coulomb's Law Img.png](data:image/png;base64,)
- In this equation, $k$ is Coulomb's constant, $q_{1} \text{ and } q_{2}$ is the magnitudes of the charges. 
- Electromagnetic force pushing two electrons apart is $10^{42}$ times that of gravitational attraction pulling them together. 
- Charge originates from subatomic particlesâ€”the proton and the electron. Charges are a conserved quantity and thus the net charge in an isolated system will always remain constant. 
- Each electron carries a charge of $-1.6022 \times10^{-19}$ coulombs, and protons the same (but a positive value.) 
- Charge can be measured through various devices such as the electroscope. 

## Electric Current
- The movement of an electric charge is known as electric current. The intensity of electric current is measured in amperes. Current can consist of any moving charged particles and can flow through conductors but not insulators.
- The process of electric current passing through a material is known as electrical conduction. Examples include current passing through conductors such as metal or electrolysis as it passes through water. 
- Current is divided into direct current and alternating current.
	- Direct current is unidirectional flow of electric charge and can be seen in batteries and most electronic devices.
	- Alternating current is current that periodically reverses its direction, making it similar to a sine wave.
